elements.title: Phallichthys (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Phallichthys (literally 'penis fish') species are so called because the males (example pictured) have "comparatively huge" sex appendages?

elements.title: Netsafe (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the organisation Netsafe created an email chatbot that replies to scammers with questions indefinitely?

elements.title: Battle of Dibrivka (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that 30 Ukrainian anarchists defeated more than 500 Austrian imperial soldiers at the Battle of Dibrivka?

elements.title: Clark Street station (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that in the 1920s, a guard was posted outside the New York City Subway's Clark Street station to prevent sailors from using it at night?

elements.title: El Yucateco (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that El Yucateco was the first Mexican brand of hot sauce sold in the United States?

elements.title: Le langaige du Bresil (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Le langaige du Bresil, one of the earliest documentary sources of any South American language, demonstrates that Europeans and Brazilian indigenous peoples maintained intimate social contacts?

elements.title: a Honolulu TV station (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the Japanese-language children's show Kikaida, popularized in Hawaii by a Honolulu TV station, beat Sesame Street in the local ratings?

elements.title: a famine in Fatimid Egypt (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that cannibals used hooks to kidnap people during a famine in Fatimid Egypt?
